unnormalised: **Environmental News Snippet: Maharashtra Forest Department Boosts Tiger Conservation Efforts**
normalised: Mumbai, Maharashtra - The Maharashtra Forest Department, in collaboration with the Wildlife Institute of India (W I I), has announced a significant expansion of tiger conservation initiatives within the Tadoba-Andhari Tiger Reserve. Doctor Anjali Patil, Chief Conservator of Forests, stated that rupees fifty lakh has been allocated for enhanced anti-poaching patrols and habitat management programs.

unnormalised: Mumbai, Maharashtra - The Maharashtra Forest Department, in collaboration with the Wildlife Institute of India (WII), has announced a significant expansion of tiger conservation initiatives within the Tadoba-Andhari Tiger Reserve. Dr. Anjali Patil, Chief Conservator of Forests, stated that Rs. 50 lakh has been allocated for enhanced anti-poaching patrols and habitat management programs.
normalised: New camera trap networks spanning over five hundred square kilometer will be established to monitor tiger populations and their movements more effectively. Furthermore, efforts are underway to mitigate human-wildlife conflict through community-based conservation programs in villages bordering the reserve. These programs aim to provide alternative livelihood options and promote co-existence. A recent study indicated a decline in ungulate populations, prompting initiatives to improve prey base availability. The department is also working on reforestation projects, focusing on native species to improve the overall forest ecosystem and expand the tigers' hunting grounds. The initiatives reflect India's commitment to Project Tiger, a flagship conservation program.

unnormalised: New camera trap networks spanning over 500 sq km will be established to monitor tiger populations and their movements more effectively. Furthermore, efforts are underway to mitigate human-wildlife conflict through community-based conservation programs in villages bordering the reserve. These programs aim to provide alternative livelihood options and promote co-existence. A recent study indicated a decline in ungulate populations, prompting initiatives to improve prey base availability. The department is also working on reforestation projects, focusing on native species to improve the overall forest ecosystem and expand the tigers' hunting grounds. The initiatives reflect India's commitment to Project Tiger, a flagship conservation program.
